summary: To find out if his reality is a physical or mental construct, Mr. Anderson, aka Neo, will have to choose to follow the white rabbit once more. If he's learned anything, it's that choice, while an illusion, is still the only way out of -- or into -- the Matrix. Neo already knows what he has to do, but what he doesn't yet know is that the Matrix is stronger, more secure and far more dangerous than ever before.

reviews.content: He is not Neo, he is John Wicky.

A pesar de que todo acabo en la tercera película, Matrix regreso con esta película que si bien haya gustado o no al público, da a entender que cada vez que un conflicto termina, siempre empieza uno nuevo. Se trata de una película muy diferente donde ya han pasado muchos años y todo ha cambiado. En la vida las cosas siempre cambian y las películas también. Uno de los puntos débiles de esta película es tener solo a Lana Wachowski a cargo, ya que Matrix ha sido creada por 2 mentes y parece que fue un reto dejar esta película a cargo de solo una de las mentes responsables. La película juega con el espectador al inicio, llegando al punto de casi romper la cuarta pared llena de metáforas sobre la sobreexplotación de una saga conocida e indicios de lo que Lana paso durante la creación de esta película solo para complacer a la Waner Bros. Nos presenta lo que ha sucedido después del final de la trilogía y una nueva Matrix que explora la condición humana a través de las emociones. La Matrix del inicio siempre iba con base en la exploración de la naturaleza humana de modo matemático, como si los humanos fueran solo algo cuyos movimientos y acciones se pueden calcular fríamente. Aquí tenemos una Matrix que explora la humanidad con base en las ilusiones que generan las emociones humanas. La filosofía de esta película es en como las emociones nos hacen creer en falsas esperanzas al punto de vivir en un sueño o una falsa ilusión creado por nuestro subconsciente. Paradógicamente, esto involucra el factor nostalgia que esta película generó en su estreno a todos los fanáticos de la saga. Eso hace que esta película sea bastante curiosa y la forma en que parece contar nuevamente la trama de la primera película, pero siendo un nuevo inicio para una nueva historia que comenzó con el final de la trilogía original. Keanu Reeves y Carrie-Anne Moss hacen un buen regreso a la saga manteniéndose fieles a sus personajes, aunque tenemos a un Neo que recién regresa y tiene que volver a recuperar sus fuerzas. El Morfeo que todo conocimos ahora es reemplazado por una versión digital del personaje que es una hibridación del Morfeo original con el Agente Smith, aunque no está a la altura de Laurence Fishburne. Finalmente, tenemos un Agente Smith reconstruido y rediseñado que ya no parece ser una amenaza, pero nos hace extrañar al Agente Smith de Hugo Weaving. Los efectos visuales son sin duda lo mejor, hay buenas escenas de acción, pero no tan excitantes como en las películas anteriores y la banda sonora es decente aún sin Don Davis. The Matrix Resurrections es una nueva ampliación al universo de Matrix, pero que en comparación con las demás películas acaba siendo una secuela hecha solo para explotar la fama de la saga. Mi clasificación final para esta película es un 8/10.
If Hell is real, I just hope it's eternal flames and not this movie on infinite repeat

The Matrix Resurrections was an exciting watch and would have been an interesting standalone film. But it couldn't seem to decide if it wanted to pay homage to the originals, or leave them behind. It built on previous plot points but used a totally different tone and style. It used new actors, but played the part of old characters. The plot became rather confusing towards the end, and the exposition started to become visibly convenient for telling the story. Many of the decisions of the characters became confusing as their goals became muddled and the audience was left unsure of what to root for. What does Agent smith want? What is he doing there? Does Naomi want safety for IO, or to use it's resources to rescue neo and his girlfriend? What does neo actually want? The originals made what was desired clear: freedom.

The action was well choreographed but didn't seem to get the respect and space it deserved within the film. Fight scenes were crammed together with little foreplay, contrasting to the originals in which fight scenes were slowly built into (cast your mind back to the subway fight between neo and smith, which took a big chunk of the original), with the viewer getting no time to develop an appreciation of the gravity of such events. It's a problem many mainstream (and less critically acclaimed) films now have - they forget to breathe. There's no time for the viewer to get attached and instead we're thrust right into the action, which is ironic in this case, because the Matrix 4 seemed to be making a commentary about this very behavior in our day-to-day lives as we pull the shroud of endless Tiktok and Twitter feeds over our eyes and away from reality (or maybe that's just me.)

The film started off promising, this time once again leaving the viewer in a state of doubt as we witnessed Thomas Anderson wrestle with past memories of Neo, but the curtain was quickly lifted as the script became visible in the form of flat, unnecessary dialogue and marvel-style jokes. The original films set a serious tone, one that allowed a sense of derealization that was left with viewers, which was probably what cemented its place as a sci-fi classic. 

The Matrix has a rich universe that is waiting to be explored, as glimpsed by some of the excellent work in the Animatrix. It is a shame this film did not better explore this, beyond some of the 'sentients' that were now living with humans. It would have been exciting to see some of the events prior The Matrix.

"The Matrix Resurrections" is the fourth installment in the highly popular and beloved "Matrix" franchise. The film is directed by Lana Wachowski and stars Keanu Reeves, Carrie-Anne Moss, Yahya Abdul-Mateen II, and Neil Patrick Harris, among others.

The plot of the film follows Thomas "Neo" Anderson (Keanu Reeves), who is now a shell of his former self, living a mundane life as a game developer. However, Neo soon discovers that his previous life in the Matrix may not have been a dream after all, and that he must once again fight against the machines to save humanity.

One of the strongest aspects of the film is the outstanding performances by the cast. Keanu Reeves once again shines in his role as Neo, delivering a performance that is both nuanced and powerful. Carrie-Anne Moss also impresses in her return as Trinity, bringing a much-needed sense of emotional depth to the film.

The action sequences in the film are also incredibly well done. From the breathtaking fight scenes to the awe-inspiring visual effects, "The Matrix Resurrections" delivers on the excitement that fans have come to expect from the franchise.

However, The Matrix Resurrections falls short compared to the original, and there are also some notable weaknesses in the film. The pacing of the story feels a bit uneven at times, with some scenes dragging on while others feel rushed. Additionally, the film's attempts to explore new themes and ideas, while admirable, can come across as heavy-handed and confusing at times.

Overall, "The Matrix Resurrections" is a solid addition to the franchise, with some truly standout moments and performances. While it may not be as groundbreaking or memorable as the original film, it is still an enjoyable and thrilling ride for fans of the series.

The concepts that the film explores are, just as the original trilogy, interesting and original. Very rarely are movie-goers treated to a perfect homage to a revisited franchise, while adding a fresh take and perspective on the source materials. Here is the idea of literally resurrecting a franchise, explored through a film. A perfect commentary for the current state of big motion pictures in this film era. Resurrections is like both a reboot and a sequel, in that several characters' actor portrayals are rebooted, while at the same time keeping in tact their original story-line from the original trilogy. This makes for an interesting reflection of self and identity. Hate to sound woke, but as we know, the Wachowskis have always explored what it means to be you and your definition of yourself. The matrix franchise has constantly explored having an identity that's incongruous with how others perceive you. Lana was able to continue the story of the original trilogy while also introducing new actors, unlike many requels that simply bring back the old, tired cast, or recast a bunch of gen-zers. So why isn't Hugo Weaving playing Agent Smith, or Lawrence Fishburne playing Morpheus? The film addresses that. They are deceased. The Morpheus in Resurrections is an NPC designed by Neo that became self-aware after Neo programmed him with that ability. The Agent Smith in Resurrections is a new Smith created by The Analyst because it became clear to him while creating the new Matrix that there was a special bond between Neo and Smith; basically, one cannot exist without the other. I wager that many people dissatisfied with the film do not actually know these plot points, which is still arguably the fault of the filmmakers, but it's not completely unsubstantiated by the screenplay and lore. It's possible that those audience members who despise the film are in fact, living in the newly created matrix.

To alleviate this I rewatched the third one as a refresher, along with my cat shengy. Upon completion of aforementioned third installment I strongly felt this was two hours of my life I would never get back, but still held a glint of hope for resurrections to right these wrongs. It did not. The wachowski family now owe me another two hours of irretrievable down time. In retroflection, I now also feel the second film nowhere nearly stood up to the magnitude and ground breaking cinematography of the original, which I feel was amazing. In summary, the wachowskis are owe me six hours movie time, I'll deduct a half hour for shengys enjoyment as I like cats

In the end the film doesn't capture the Magic of the original matrix but could give die hard fans the nostalgia trip there were look for.

This review may contain spoilers.

Woof. Just…just woof. 

I can't tell if this movie is pretentious & boring, or clever and deliberate. I can't tell if it's trying to be metaphorical or just meta…or some weird combination of both. 

Just like all the other sequels, I found myself bored and confused and checked out by the halfway mark. 

NPH is definitely the most entertaining part of the movie, but just like his Architect predecessor from the second movie, he spends most of his time making long winded speeches that don't really go anywhere, leaving the viewer scratching their head and wondering what the hell just happened.

To say the stakes of the movie are unclear is an understatement. The war is over, but at the same time, it's not. The machines & humans are allies, but at the same time, they're not. Ultimately, it all becomes about saving one person at the risk of the world, as opposed to risking one person to save the world, as what happened in the third film. 

While I like the first Matrix film just fine, it's never been anywhere close to my list of favorite movies. Maybe the die-hard Matrix fans will be able to get more out of this than I did.

The movie is called "Resurrections". As if to indicate this property had been dead or simply on life support, finally brought back to life. But this feels more like a dead body being buried in the cursed earth of the forbidden "sematary." Now it's back from the dead; the flesh is living, but the soul is spoiled. It plays out like someone's pipe dream fan fiction, making up its own rules while still finding a way to be highly derivative and unoriginal. 

Ultimately, this feels like one time where it would've been best to simply take the blue pill, and leave things the way they were.

As far as action goes, if that's what you're looking for with a Matrix movie, then this probably isn't going to satisfy, but as far as ideas go this has it in spades. Too many ideas in fact; some could even say it's loaded to the point of convolution. For me though, it was a nice return to the franchise, one that actually gives you things to think about. And it features tons of heart in being even more of a love story than the original trilogy. I dug it, and I suspect that I'll like it even more with subsequent viewings and digging further into the themes.

As a huge fan of the original film and a Matrix lore nerd, I had high hopes for the 4th instalment. Sadly, I was disappointed. The action scenes seem lazy and poorly choreographed by comparison to the other Matrix films. To sum it up, this film just isn't up to scratch. There were scenes where I literally laughed out loud, not because they were intentionally funny, but because of how poorly directed certain scenes were. By the films half way mark, my hand was down my date's pants and I had absolutely no interest in what the film had to say. The lowlight for me was the corny ending with its ham-fisted feminist allegory. I have no problem pretending this film doesn't exist and I am convinced that fans of the 4th instalment have taken the blue pill.

The Matrix Resurrections aunque es mejor que sus 2 atnecesoras, en el género de acción se queda algo corta, Lana Wachowski sigue impregnando su visión en esta película que junto al fantástico Keanu Reeves reviven el sentimiento de los 2000', con una psica de modernidad en el vestuario y en los diálogos. Me parece que el principal divisior de esta película esta en que puede llegar a ser un poco pretenciosa, profundizando demás los diálogos y haciendolos confusos sin razón. No hay un planteamiento real que justifique todos los diálogos en la película, muchos se seinten forzados y de más en la cinta, como si se basaran en la superficialidad para crear capas en la historia; llegando a precer en varios momentos diálogos irónicos. Como la escena del la pélea en la que hay un personaje que dice cosas al aire para "maticar" el conflicto exterior de la cinta con WB, que desde mi punto de vista no me parece ingenioso tener como conflicto principal, un conflico personal del autor, que solo entenderá el espectador que este al tanto de las noticias de esta película, ojo todos los directores (o la gran mayoría) modifican echos reales para crear su historia, hasta en la misma cinta se hace referencia, pero el problema está en que Lana Wachowski no exteriorisa su porpio conflico, no lo adapta a la historia, lo hace parecer como un berrinche, el discurso no se amolda a la trama y no se siente natural, y ojo conflico externo si crea una buena trama que va más allá de ser algo externo para profundizar la película, ya que es más fácil que el público entienda el mensaje o lo capte, porque un conflico externo afecta a todos. Para mi la trama se basa más en la busqueda el empoderamiento interno y en forjar nuestra identidad sin inspirarnos o imitar las tendencias (Libera tu mente), con la ya crítica al capitalismo que las demás cintas venian arrastrando, con una que otra alegoría interesante. Con lo que me quedo en esta película está en el montaje, cada escena ya sea de exposición del conflico o de acción, tiene planos interesantes que se hacen muy dinámicos con la historia, que se agradece sobre todo en las escenas de acción, con una paleta de colores oscuras y furtes en la que prioriza el azul que me pareció hermosa, no me aburrí de ella en toda la película, y para mi le da una profundidad en la imágen muy interesante que se vuelve agradable y en varios momentos impactánte de ver.

Para Mi Matrix 4 se hizo como una crítica a la sobre explotación de contenido actual, con Reboots y contenidos sin originalidad que buscan ser más un entretenimiento masivo sin una cara real, que una producción que busque darle un mensaje al espectador, que en varios momentos funciona pero en otros no, más allá de la fotografía esta 4 entrega no tiene otro apartado en el que sobresalga, Matrix 4 podrá ser original pero sin contar una historia que realmente sobresalga de toda la masividad de contendio que tenemos actualmente.

The 1999 "Matrix" was not a good film, it was the standard for a good film. The original idea was so good that it held on two sequels that, with all their imperfections, together form a unique trilogy. Unfortunately, we also received the fourth half-sequel, half-remake of the mentioned movie, which, if it had any spirit, could be called a parody rather than a serious film. But, we have what we have, now at least we got a standard for a bad movie, and an example of what kind of movies should not be made. It has already become proverbial for Hollywood to record "woke" propaganda, instead of slightly watchable and entertaining achievements.

To paraphrase a line from the film that best describes the reason for this misdeed itself: "Warner Brothers decided to shoot a sequel to the Matrix trilogy, with or without us." Surprisingly honest, nothing else to say. Apart from the original John Wick, pardon, Neo and Trinity, the rest of the cast consists of comic characters who, all together, can hardly bear the epithet of actors. The script and dialogues, on the other hand, are written in such a way that no serious acting would help.

The vain repetition of scenes already seen (and literally), a patched plot full of holes without any meaning, rather bad effects and a change of the original coloring are just some of the troubles this film is dealing with. It was also expected that the original story will be altered, so we find out that Neo is actually not the only "One", but that they are, in fact, Neo and Trinity, but, above all, Trinity. Everything in this film goes downhill, from the very beginning to the uninspiring ending. Cheap, just as check-out music is cheap compared to the original by RATM.

If you only can, don't waste time with this movie. It is better to spend it, for example on "Spiderman: No Way Home," and see how a fun sequel to a franchise can be recorded, with an original approach and a real look back at previous sequels. I am far from favoring so-called actors like Tom Holland or Zendaya, but the film is at least craftily done properly.

It was a daring idea to create a sequel to The Matrix that actually doesn't feel like a Matrix movie. The goal here is to reference the franchise legacy but still look like a new original experience. The idea sounds good but here it doesn't really work as the movie itself doesn't know what to be instead of a Matrix movie. A lot of the movie feels like an afterthought, lacking enough development. There is one particular moment when a character of the previous movie appears in the most random way screaming things that do feel like an improvisation while staying out of any interaction with the main cast before disappearing for good. The main villains disappoint too. Jonathan Groff doesn't have the same level of intimidation as Hugo Weaving, which is a big miss for the movie. There is another new villain too but he has too much personality and human quirk to feel like a "mean program". At one point, this same villain talks about having "inside jokes" but with who? how robots can have inside jokes? The action scenes can be fun but most of them don't live up to the memorable level of the other Matrix movies. That said, the action still is a good diversion after some very long and boring explanations that are too present in the movie. The movie is still worthy of your time if you liked the franchise, the scene between Neo and Trinity are great, their chemistry and their acting are amazing. Trinity especially shines in each of her appearances. Also, the new character, Bug, played by Jessica Henwick, is a very fun one and a pretty good addition to the franchise. Also the main theme this time is that people want to live in their own world, their mind, instead of facing reality which is pretty good for a movie that is so meta towards the first movie where the theme was the possible fakeness of our reality but Revolution doesn't develop this theme despite talking few times about it. Don't expect too much though, as many people thought, this movie seems to be the beginning of a new franchise. In Matrix Revolution, only a few things will be resolved by the end of the movie, and some important obstacles will be a little too easily cleared.

There is more wrong here than you would care to read, so I will hit the big points:
-The pacing is god awful.  It is so jarring that it ruins the occasional and rare action scenes and makes it look cheap and poorly executed.
-The acting looks terrible.  There are talented people in this movie that look awful because of the aforementioned pace and the directing.  The director should fire herself.  It definitely reeks of someone that doesn't seem to have much interest in the project.
-The rumor (and unsuccessful lawsuit) that much of the original script was ripped off from pitched scripts like the ones for Altered Carbon is looking to have more legs now than it did.  If this is what comes from the "original" creation of either Wachowski (or both), then they probably stole most of their success.

Someone actually mentioned the flop Jupiter Ascending as one of Lana's projects.  Compared to this, that movie is highly enjoyable.  This one is borderline torture for anyone that actually cares about the original masterpieces.

And NO, it's not clever.  It's contrived....clever is subtle and intricate.  This "message" is trying to beat the audience over the head with it in the most pathetically executed failure I've seen in a long time.

The first Matrix movie had a societal impact like very few other movies have had before or after and the cultural significance is still relevant to this day. I was absolutely blown away by this film and it is certainly one of my all time favorites. The sequels were not quite as good but definitely still had their moments of action, intrigue, and spectacle. After seeing Resurrections I'm now convinced that they never should've gone beyond the original. Resurrections makes Revolutions look like Citizen Kane, despite all the flaws the trilogy's finale had. I knew this latest entry to the series was not going to be as good as the original trilogy, but nothing could've prepared me for how bad this movie actually was.

The first red flag is the fact that this film has to constantly remind you of how much better the first film was. About a third of the film is either trying to sloppily recreate the most iconic scenes and imagery of the first film, or is literally just showing you those scenes within the film. Then there's all the "meta" self-awareness the film has, which could have been a clever plot device but is done in such a painfully cringy way that it feels like they don't want you to take this film seriously. Neo's powers are completely nerfed and it's pretty obvious that Keanu is now too old to do kung fu. Agent Smith and Morpheus are just cheap knock-offs of Weaving and Fishburne, and I can't blame those two for not wanting to return to this trainwreck of a sequel. Instead of the Architect we have the "Analyst" who is an actual exposition machine and explains any necessary plot points when the story needs to move forward. There are a lot of cool ideas like a machine civil war that get briefly mentioned and then are never spoken of again, even though these could've been fascinating concepts to explore. The new characters are like forgettable NPCs, which is fitting considering that the film's first angle is to say the Matrix was just a video game. They even introduce one of the most cliche concepts they could possibly throw into this franchise, zombies. Yes that's right, there are now zombies in the Matrix. You might be wondering if at least the action is any good... well, it isn't. The fight choreography also feels like a huge downgrade from the entire Matrix trilogy.

There are so many things wrong with this movie, from the script, to the casting, to the execution, and so on. It's a nostalgia-bait cash-grab that destroys everything the franchise had worked to achieve, and based on Lana Wachowski's statements this was probably intentional. I understand wanting to make a commentary about the film industry, sequels, etc., but that could've been accomplished without creating such a disjointed mess. This is one of the most disappointing sequels ever made, if not the worst sequel in the history of film. I'd prefer to be like Neo and believe that this movie is not real.

I am not a movie critic and never will be. But when I watched the matrix series when I was young, I enjoyed it a lot. This movies recreates the idea of the first one and speed through the same ideas the 2nd and 3rd did. It is an enjoyable ride again through their universe 4/5
However, what makes it my review 5/5 it is because the creators were put into a situation where the studio forced them to deliver something, which they did nicely, and gave corporates a middle finger. That is why I liked this movie so much.

The plot was even more nonsensical and convoluted than previous films, with the stupid game developer needing therapy idea, 'footage' from the original films being part of 'the game' despite games not having 'footage', revival of Neo and Trinity, Trinity being married but not actually liking her family, living alongside robots with silly names, and the cringe ending. The characters were a downgrade in every way, with a ridiculous representation of game developers, therapists, and children, and the acting and cast were much worse than before. Hearing the reactions to this film when it came out, opinions were very divided. To more casual fans who grew up with the original, it was an excessively meta take on the original with a goofy, recast Morpheus making drinks and an excessive reliance on references. However, a lot of people with crippling movie addictions saw it as something else entirely, a creative and surprisingly subversive evolution of the original that asked new questions about the nature of creativity and ideation. After setting my hopes rather low, I lean much more heavily towards the latter. Yes, Agent Smith is now a tech bro douche because they couldn't get Hugo Weaving back and anyone trying to imitate him would have fallen short. But the movie was willing to take risks where it could have played it safe by just bringing back every face that made the original a classic, leaning slightly on the love for the original but expanding the questions regarding free will and in particular, our own certainty. 

Ideally, I would have hoped that the fight scenes would have activated the stupid action movie-happy part of my brain a bit more, and that some of the character designs were a bit more restrained, and that the choices made by our protagonists carried a bit more weight. But I was still happy with the end product, and very satisfied when Trinity decided that children were overrated. (3/5)

I initially thought that some of the action scenes could have left a bit to be desired due to Keanu's age, but then I remembered John Wick and realized that it surely wasn't the acting that made the scenes disappointing.

Much like the Netflix seasons of Arrested Development, I'm sad to say The Matrix Resurrections would have been better off not made.

Despite a few nostalgic feelings (that are quickly overwhelmed by other feelings), it's very clear ‘The Matrix: Resurrections' is missing almost everything that made the original trilogy so iconic. It feels sanitized, overly-polished, dumbed down and, quite frankly, rather pointless. There are no interesting characters, no clever and philosophical plot-points; the action feels amateurish and is badly filmed. What struck me most of all was just how off the vibe was, and that was in great part due to the cinematography and production design. It almost feels like a fan-made affair with a big budget, directed by someone who completely misunderstood everything about the original films and couldn't find anything even remotely new or interesting to add to the conversation (I can see why Lilly Wachowski wanted nothing to do with this). Sure, if this is your first experience with anything Matrix related, maybe you can find something to enjoy, but for most established fans, I don't see this cash-grab being anything but an immense disappointment.

So rare is it to see a film, where in every word, and in every scene, the creator can be seen within the work. This was such a beautifully precise execution of storytelling, that on my first watch of it, I know many more viewings will be necessary to grasp what Lana Wachowski has gifted us.

The first half was amazing; deep and philosophical, with good action sequences and dialogue. What was remarkable was it was also simultaneously humorous, very knowingly mocking itself without diluting the story at all (you'll need to watch it to understand, but I've personally labelled it as 'breaking the fifth wall' in a very meta sort of way).

Unfortunately into the second half it fell apart a bit for me. It just got way too convoluted, and whilst I more or less followed it I'll need to re-read the plot on Wikipedia to get my head around the finer points. The brilliance of the first half (which I'd easily give 5* to) fizzled out, and we were left with something that was a bit boring, illogical and poorly executed, with the dialogue even getting a bit hammy.

So overall a 3* rating - if it could have kept up the quality of the first half this would have gone down as a historic sequel, but sadly it fell short, a bit like Neo's failed jump in the first film :-( Definitely better than the two original sequels though.

Director Lana Wachowski's sci-fi action-adventure The Matrix Resurrections (2021) is a good movie that I enjoyed much of, while absolutely loathing certain choices. Wachowski's direction only has that sleek neo-noir style from The Matrix during the scenes within The Matrix, while the real world segments feel dull for Io just like Zion from Reloaded and Revolutions. I do appreciate Lana Wachowski returning to direct with some style of her own and providing some heart to this story. However, The Matrix Resurrections has as many problems as it has enjoyable scenes.

Production designers Hugh Bateup and Peter Walpole beautifully recreate The Machine City and people pods, while The Matrix office and cafe sets sucks horribly. Io looks just like Zion: hideous. Some of the visual effects are remarkable like hands going through mirrors, machines plugging into people, characters appearing or morphing suddenly. However, the bullet dodge CGI and slowing down effects look cheap and rough. How can The Matrix effects look worse now than 20 years ago?

Editor Joseph Jett Sally's montages cutting back and forth between the old Matrix movies and the new ones are obnoxious and terrible. Generally, the editing is dull and unimaginative without real tension or pacing in mind. The Matrix Resurrections starts with an unbearable first 40 minutes with insufferable new characters that could easily have been cut. It did not need to be 148 minutes long at all. The Matrix Resurrections could have had a quick montage to demonstrate that Neo is unhappy in The Matrix and felt like reality was not real, then gets the red pill from Morpheus and gets to the interesting plot. I hated the opening, loved the middle section of The Matrix Resurrections that has new plot, places, and ideas, then felt cold about the lackluster ending.

I hated how the conversations are shot like television episodes, yet there are some striking wide shots with real mood from cinematographers John Toll and Daniele Massaccesi. Neo rising from the machine pods or walking in the rain at night look incredible like the original Matrix films. However much of the martial arts fight choreography is basic and not thrilling like the old kung fu. The gun shootouts are pretty dull and the final riot attack is pretty boring. This should have been so easy to look and feel cool! The fast paced, action packed, and brilliant science-fiction sequences are just not here within The Matrix Resurrections.

This movie was obviously mandated by Warner Brothers, so Lana Wachowski directed and wrote what she could come up with to not let them create something completely terrible. Instead, we got a creative movie with some fresh sci-fi ideas, bland action, half awful acting, and a jaded perspective.

Writers Lana Wachowski, David Mitchell, and Aleksandar Hemon clearly resent Warner Brothers as well as fans of The Matrix for wanting another Matrix sequel. The meta references and jokes are horrendous, unfunny, unimaginative, confusing, and hurt the otherwise serious tone of The Matrix movies. The Matrix Resurrections carries a contrived, jaded, and cynical perspective without much hope compared to The Matrix Trilogy. Neo and Trinity's romance needed to be developed further as we barely got any Carrie-Anne Moss until the end! I kind of loved how the machines resurrect and recreate Neo and Trinity's bodies. This film needed more interesting ideas like that or humanity's last remaining city Io living in harmony with humans and machines. I do not appreciate Laurence Fishburne, Hugo Weaving, or even the actress that played Sati not getting to return to their respective characters. Their absence is notable.

Keanu Reeves is pretty good as Neo once more in The Matrix Resurrections. He's sometimes really awkward or bored, but he delivers a serious and thoughtful performance as Neo realizes the consequences of what he's done or how the world changed or didn't. Neo should have been allowed to fight with some complex kung fu more as there's very little action surprisingly. He's still got romantic chemistry with Carrie-Anne Moss, but they needed more screen-time together. She has not aged a day really as Carrie-Anne Moss is absolutely gorgeous still and a cool heroine with her iconic Trinity. Carrie-Anne Moss is fantastic as Trinity once she gets to fight, but she's wasted having her pretend to be Tiffany. Hopefully, if there is somehow a fifth Matrix film, Keanu Reeves and Carrie-Anne Moss can be together the entire film.

Yahya Abdul-Mateen II is serious and gripping as Morpheus, but I just wish Laurence Fishburne was asked back as his iconic black hero. Morpheus' fight with Neo in the water dojo is pretty neat. Jessica Henwick is wonderful, beautiful, and cool as Bugs. I wish she wasn't forgotten about by the end and given an even bigger role as she's charismatic, cool, and funny. She gets how to make Bugs feel intriguing and strong with a worry for the future as she believes in Neo like the old Morpheus. I am certainly surprised at how cute and fun Jessica Henwick is in The Matrix Resurrections. Yahya Abdul-Mateen II and Jessica Henwick are definitely pleasant standouts from The Matrix Resurrections as far as the new cast is concerned.

Jonathan Groff is so average as Agent Smith. He does not have Hugo Weaving's charismatic delivery, heavy enunciation, distinct voice, fearsome presence, or captivating gravitas. I could not help but think how cool every line of Smith's would sound if he was played by Hugo Weaving again. Neil Patrick Harris is fairly gripping and often funny as The Analyst. He's a great improvement on The Architect's obnoxious personality and dense dialogue. Priyanka Chopra sounds like she's just reading her lines off the script. She's the worst performance in the entire movie and I'm shocked she was used to help promote it at all. They should have gotten the Indian girl who originally played Sati so charmingly. She could not possibly be worse than Priyanka.

Christina Ricci looks breathtaking and she's so funny! How does she only get like two lines of dialogue then she disappears? She would have been way better than any other person in The Matrix. They could have at least made her character Gwyn de Vere an agent or something. Jada Pinkett Smith is both engaging and awful as a newly jaded Niobe. She's not brave or loyal at all anymore. Telma Hopkins is okay as researcher Freya. Chad Stahelski is terrible as Chad, but it's a quaint cameo, I guess. Lambert Wilson is surprisingly terrible and raving as The Merovingian. He used to be one of the best parts of Reloaded and Revolutions. Brian J. Smith's Berg is boring. Toby Onwumere's Sequoia is somehow worse than Tank or Link. Max Riemelt is likable as Sheperd, but he does nothing. Eréndira Ibarra's Lexy is very pretty and rather emotional, so I'm surprised she's barely used in The Matrix Resurrections. Andrew Lewis Caldwell truly awful as the meta spewing game design dork Jude. He's unbearable. Honestly, half the cast is insufferable, while the half that is great are underused.

Composers Tom Tykwer and Johnny Klimek's score is underwhelming, honestly. I miss the grand symphonic pieces from Don Davis or Juno Reactor's exciting techno songs. Where are all the exciting, beautiful, or memorable themes or melodies? Surely they could have had pulsing synths or something for The Matrix Resurrections? Sound design is both corny and slick with some robots sounding neat and other action sounds coming across as goofy. Lindsay Pugh, Caroline Hill, and Javier Arrieta's costumes are so boring and ugly compared to any of Kym Barrett's classic Matrix outfits. Where is all the leather, latex, and black fabrics? This looks so ugly and modern. The make-up team ensures everyone looks older, that's for sure.

In short, I'm not impressed by the overall execution, but I appreciate The Matrix Resurrections ambition. I wish it had more striking visuals like the actual resurrection or thrilling action like Neo fighting Morpheus.

The first act of this film is meta, really really meta. It's so meta that they may as well have been winking at the camera, but winking with both eyes at the same time because of how poorly done it was. It reminded me of what Space Jam: New Legacy was, just one big promo for Warner Bros. As soon as they said "our partner, Warner Bros want a sequel" I just wanted to die.

At first, I thought it was an interesting way to imprison Neo, by making him think he was the video game designer of The Matrix and everything that happened in the first three movies was all in his head. However the writing and the scenes were dumb, I had to cover my eyes. It felt like everything the first three movies did was for nothing.

Then eventually it started to feel like a Matrix sequel in the second act, once Neo got brought back. It was cool that Keanu shaved his head for it, it really felt like Neo was truly back. However, when we met the secondary characters. I really didn't like most of them. They always feel like they have to add a cast of young secondary characters to make the movie seem more 'with the times'? I've never thought Jessica Henwick was a good actress, she didn't feel like a Matrix character. I'm sure those who have seen Sense8 noticed a few familiar faces though. Casting Jonathan Groff and Neil Patrick Harris were weird ones, because their faces aren't ominous in the slightest to be the villains, they just looked like regular dudes, repeating lines from the old movies, trying to be modern versions of The Architect and Agent Smith.

What was funny about them constantly playing scenes from the old movies was that it reminded us how much better they were compared to what we were currently watching.

What this movie lacked was the sophistication that the first few movies had. Instead of Neo and Trinity looking like bad asses, it was just messy action sequences with force pushes? Granted, Keanu Reeves seemed like one of the few people there actually putting some effort in, because alongside him was Carrie Anne-Moss, who didn't seem like she wanted to be there.

That brings me to the directing. I personally think the Wachowskis got super freaking lucky with the first Matrix being one of the best Sci-Fi movies ever made. Some of the shots in this movie looked like shots you'd see in a behind-the-scenes featurette. The sets looked like movie sets and kind of low budget. It was all so poorly done that it kept taking me out of the experience.

This movie only felt like a Matrix movie when they were in the real world, but even then, the lack of that grittiness and the green-y filter made it feel like it was lacking The Matrix feel.

I'll admit, the new human settlement looked great! That was all until Jada Pinkett-Smith entered the frame and we saw her terrible performance and the terrible old-person makeup done on her. It was painful to look at. Then on to explaining how Morpheus was there but also not there, really confused the hell out of me. It's like they didn't even know themselves why Lawrence Fishburne wasn't there, they just wanted to be able to have a character called Morpheus in the movie, but just played by someone else?

Some visual and audio editing was also really shoddy. You could tell this was a rushed job that Warner Bros just wanted to get made. It was obvious to see all the red flags in the promo for this film, it didn't feel like the real deal. The Wachowskis haven't made a decent movie for a long time, why would one of them suddenly conjure up the skill to finally make a good movie? They should've just given the movie to someone else to make. But who knows, maybe this movie was doomed to fail either way, because you can tell that Warner Bros had some "creative input". And if different director were to failed, then the fans would complain and say the Wachowskis should've made it. After all, they created The Matrix world, but like George Lucas did with Star Wars, they ran a great thing into the ground by trying to build on it (but yes, Revenge of the Sith was incredible).

A messy film, but so were the 2nd and 3rd movie and I loved those. The meta commentary about the entertainment industry and the contemporary landscape for artists in the age of corporate IPs was perhaps on the nose, but that doesn't make it any less relevant. And it was only the most obvious metaphor on display, with many deeper layers of symbolism and allegory going on. As a trans person, I was very touched by the potent allegories for our experience. And as a communist, I was blown away by the salient critiques of capitalist realism and the society of spectacle. There were many layers of philosophical depth which kept me thinking for weeks after seeing it.
It wasn't what I expected, I was disappointed, the argument was terrible, this movie shouldn't have been made when the cycle of this franchise was already closed.

22 anos atrás, Matrix foi lançado para o mundo, mudando completamente o cinema, e introduzindo um conceito que ficaria nas mentes das pessoas: "O que é real?". A trilogia original surfou na onda da virada do milênio e todas as questões filosóficas sobre a tecnologia que vieram junto, e fez isso muito bem, criando uma mitologia que não vai te explicar seus significados, mas fazer você questioná-los.

A trilogia terminou em um filme fraco, mas que encerrava de uma maneira coesa e satisfatória a história de #Neo e #Trinity, o que levantou uma grande pergunta quando a sequencia foi anunciada: Será que valia mesmo a pena continuar essa história? E a resposta é que não! #Ressurections não tenta ser uma continuação ou um fechamento e sim um grande e cômico exercício de metalinguagem, que serve apenas pra atualizar as analogias de Matrix com a sociedade de 2021.

O filme não vai tentar te explicar o que é a Matrix, mas ele vai tentar te cativar pela nostalgia. O filme é completamente dependente daquilo que veio antes, fazendo incessantes paralelos entre o que você está vendo e o que você já viu, e isso porque o próprio roteiro não é profundo o bastante pra prender a sua atenção. E se você está esperando cenas de luta dignas da obra original... Vai se decepcionar! O filme abre mão dos combates bem coreografados para dar lugar aos poderes da computação gráfica e ele ainda te explica o porque: Nossos protagonistas estão velhos! O filme não tenta mascarar isso em momento nenhum... na verdade, adota pra sua narrativa num dos poucos pontos positivos.

Com esse filme, Matrix deixa de ser uma critica a sociedade, e passa a ser uma critica ao modo hollywoodiano de se viver e de se correr com a vida, utilizando de um humor ácido e escrachado pra isso. E sobre a nova roupagem de velhos personagens... A resposta é que eles nem de perto fazem jus ao que eram, mas talvez brilhem do seu próprio jeito, com exceção de Trinity que finalmente ganha o espaço e o poder que sempre mereceu, quando você percebe que o filme de fato, foi feio para ela.

Here I am, to talk about a resounding flop, in all respects, and I'm not kidding. 
Matrix Resurrection is the fourth chapter in the Matrix franchise, it is pathetic and not epic, not like those of the original trilogy, which are fantastic and wonderful, while this film is very ugly 
By the direction of only Lana from The Wachowski, thinking about it, it was as if the director knew that this film was useless, but she did not want to finish a story that is like a perfect cycle. 
It's very sad how the audience associates the name "Wachowski" only with Matrix, every time the sisters want to do a new film, it reveals as a flop because "Wachowski" is only Matrix. 

It is like a fanfiction, everything is explained, how but don't why, there isn't space for the interpretation or for the philosophical concepts. When you go to the cinema and you know you're going to watch Matrix, you expect, from this film, to deal with important themes with deep and complicated philosophical meanings, you certainly don't expect to watch a film that seems to be written on Wattpad.
For instance, it is like a Disney film, yeah for kids, as if the director took the old trilogy, mixed it with a children's film and here we are, Matrix Resurrections. In addition, all the irony moments seems like for the children, but, obvious, the children don't watch this film because the Matrix Franchise (I mean only the old ones) isn't for kids. 
In support of this, some dialogues are put into the mouths of adults who would never use that kind of expression, that kind of slang, only for pleasing the public, 
This film's very didactic and simple, it shows everything to the viewer who already knows what he is going to watch. The film is mediocre, only for give the audience what it want and not for be original and surprise it, in substance, the film is a modern version that fits in with today's standards like a piece of a jigsaw puzzle, in summary, a fanservice. 

Changing argument, there isn't significance over the characters, there isn't interests over what they do, in particular the new ones. 
The characters have aged and when they move to fight, they are floppy and not as agile as they used to be, you look at them and think: what are they doing there? 
But in the end, it's not their fault, it's just life cycle.
The characters from this film are like a parody of themselves, and talking about parodies, the parody of excellence, Yahya Abdul-Mateen II's Morpheus. 
What is he doing there? Why did they do that? 
Because in the end there was no need for this character, just with his presence he ruins the existence of the original Morpheus, the god of dreams, I feel bad just thinking about it. But for heaven's sake the actor is good, but I just don't understand the need for a new Morpheus who moreover keeps saying he's a sort of copy of the original, who just tries to imitate him as best as possible, like I said, it's a parody. 
But we want to talk about Neo, alias of Thomas Anderson? 
Keanu Reeves is a fantastic actor and there is no need that I say that, but in this film, he is floppy and transmits depression, you just have to look at he to feel sad. In addiction his presence isn't justified, or better, they explain "how" but not "why" he is what he's. 
Somewhat like the presence of Trinity, interpreted, as always, by Carrie-Anne Moss. 
One of the biggest problems of this film is the fact that they use the concept of girl power too much, let me explain, they give Trinity play the role of the woman in love who defeats everything, there was no need for that, Trinity doesn't need " the girl power" because she's been like that since the beginning, even before they invented it. She's been a very strong woman who, let's say, didn't meet the standards of the time, she had, and still has, short hair with lots of gel, leather suits, motorbikes, and guns. 
It is a nonsensical concept for Trinity because her DNA has always been that of a warrior woman and not that of a damsel to be rescued who surprises everyone with a bit of luck. 
Let's talk about the enemies of Neo, the Agent Smith, in the original trilogy he had a very important role for the film, he was a character well done. There isn't a logical reason for his existence, he doesn't have sense and is practically useless, in fact, without him the story would have been the same, but this reflection, it wouldn't apply to the first three films, because as already mentioned, Agent Smith plays a really important role, particularly in the second and third film. 

The plot is practically copied, full of reshooting, for example; the white rabbit that reminds "Alice in Wonderland", the black cat, the red and blue pill, and EVEN the bullet time. All the things I've just enumerated, they take away all the mysteries and questions that were in the first films. 
As I said before, the plot is practically the same at the first film (the one from 1999), it's like when you give a classmate something to copy at school and he changes something to avoid making it too obvious, in short, the key word is "parallelism". 
The moments that should be funny interrupt the audience's immersion in the important moments and they detach it from the film, by consolidating the fourth wall and not trying to demolish it. In general, the audience wants to immerse themselves in the film, feel a multitude of emotions and have new experiences. In this, the audience knows they are watching it from a screen and not as part of it, they are not taken in. As if that were not enough, there're a lot of combatants that don't have an impact in the story, they don't have a sense and add nothing to the film, unlike those in the first three films, because there is always justified, and let me say it, all the choreography and pits are terrible. 
Moreover, this film is too much nostalgic over the others before, there are a lot of flashback and references really useless, precisely for remind you it is a reboot. 
Changing subject and going more technical, aesthetics, photography and cinematography, original are ruined. Before there was this strong green filter that made almost all the colors inside the Matrix, green or black, moreover, you could understand if the characters are inside the Matrix or not, thanks to the colors, in fact when they were in the real world the dominating colors were blue and grey, colors often associated with technology and the future, while inside the Matrix, precisely, this scale of green and black gave a feeling of unreality and unease. 
In the fourth film this important play of colors is lost, and the latter tend to be those of a blockbuster, moreover, it is no longer clear when the characters are actually inside the Matrix. 
Additionally, the bullet time. When the people think at Matrix, they think at Neo dodging bullets while is bent over in an unnatural position, the bullet time is nearly a trademark of Matrix, also this thing is lost in the fourth chapiter. The effects in general aren't very beautiful, with the modern conception of the world we have today, it is unthinkable that a film of 99 has more beautiful effects than one of 2021, that is, 22 years have passed, the situation should be improved, with this I say that if we compare the different films, the CGI in the former is much higher than that of this hideous film. 

Summarized, Matrix Resurrections doesn't have a reason to exist because it has a narrative power inexistent, it doesn't add anything and is useless. This movie is a horrible version of the original trilogy, a forgone movie, only with its presence, it ruins the first three movie. 
The only reason to watch it, is for making your opinion about it.

The Matrix Resurrections celebrates everything that fans love about the original trilogy – the philosophical commentary, the slow motion action sequences, and the amazing lore of this world. Just as one should expect from another entry in the Matrix franchise, Resurrections will have you questioning reality and your own existence as you watch the characters move forward in this visually stunning film.

The callbacks to the original version are not that subtle, but are justified in the context of the film's plot, so count them as more than just nostalgic fan bait.

Neo is back, and Keanu Reeves' portrayal feels familiar but also more nuanced as he's grown in his career. The older physical features are welcomed as they feel natural because they are. No presence of de-aging CGI as far as I could tell.

While the first three Matrix films are visually defined by the classic green on black iconography and dark hues to portray a conflict against oppressive machines, Matrix Resurrections is a visual masterpiece that deserves a theatrical viewing by fans. Whether it's a portrayal of life or a simulation of it, the world building shots of this film are awe-inspiring and feel like the next evolution for this franchise.

Without giving away too much, by the last third of the film, new ground is broken for the series as the thematic focus is brought center stage for fans to see play out amongst these characters, new and old.

Nothing was making sense, I felt almost like I was having the stroke all over again... thank god that I wasnt the only one that absolutely nothing was making sense for.  We all 4 who were watching this got halfway through the movie before we all gave up trying to make sense of it.  Those who liked it, good on them, but for us no... this was just a confusing mess.  No thanks we wont be back to see this one, we will keep our trillogy and carry on life without paying any notice to this horrendous 4th movie to the series.

Following in the footsteps of other big franchises, The Matrix Resurrections (2021) brings back the franchise many years after it seemingly ended. Where those franchises adapt a similar plot to the original, this sequel plays it too close to how The Matrix (1999) flows for the first half, overdoing it with the fan service. Besides that instance where The Matrix Resurrections (2021) feels like a copy of the original, this film is extremely ambitious with how experimental and self aware it is. After the initial trilogy ended in a natural way, this film had to do something different to justify a fourth film, and while it does, it doesn't entirely work, instead making this film a convoluted mess, relying too much on forced fan service.

The action and effects are good, with some creative visual shots, but overall it doesn't make up for many issues this film does have. The recast of Morpheus and Agent Smith was a bold decision and while it attempts to be justified it just doesn't work, despite their best attempts Yahya Abdul-Mateen II and Jonathan Groff just don't match up to Laurence Fishburn and Hugo Weaving.

While it will earn respect for trying some things new, The Matrix Resurrections (2021) proves that not every franchise revival works.

Lana Wachowski has allowed us to return to the Matrix and revisit our favourite characters. Even if it was somehow different to the original trilogy, its structure is visibly reminiscent of the first movie. Once again, Mr. Anderson is split between two choices: staying where he apparently belongs to or question his world and find out if his reality is a physical or mental construct. Neo already knows what he has to do, but what he doesn't yet know is that the Matrix is stronger, more secure and far more dangerous than ever before. Visual effects are incredible and innovative in this new sequel released almost 19 years after the trilogy ended. The plot is incredibly meta and yet so down-to-earth that the script is worthy of mention for that. I like how it ended but I believe it should be left as a stand-alone movie. But it was really entertaining overall. Finally, the Sense 8 cast is back! 😃

Watch it if you have HBO Max, especially in the spirit of completionism. But if you're looking for something new or an amazing version to reignite the original cast, this is not it. - BiAP Del

A movie that shouldn't have been made. A slap in the face of the fans of the original movie and series, and an embarrassment to how first film, The Matrix, which actually produced a thought provoking narrative with solid characters and a story you could get involved in. The meta-jokes from poorly imagined new characters and heavy-handed politically influenced writing were disgusting. These were nearly present and referenced in nearly every single scene, which was just simply distracting and again, unnecessary. It was overly reliant on literal past footage from the other movies shows this story cannot stand up by itself, and shows how much it was just a tack-on to a movie series, while not perfect, had a complete story which did not need to continue. 

The story heavily revolves around Neo and Trinity, which were oddly the only characters from the original series and weren't recast (Niobe or the Merv do not count). The decision to recast iconic characters like Agent Smith and Morpheus was a boned-headed decision. In that case, they should have just had a whole new cast including Neo and Trinity, making them reincarnations or something stupid like that.

Visually, it was okay, but the action scenes were shot in such a way with lighting that it was hard to even see anything. Neo only really used a fraction of his power, and they really relied on his ability to stop bullets way too much. It was sad how they used how he can't fly anymore as a joke.... ugh. Oh, but now Trinity can fly, so is she the One now? Also, the post credit scene just made me say "What? Why? Catrix? The fuck?" But it did say something interesting, indeed, movies are dead it seems, and this dumpster fire of a sequel, with all the inside jokes and self-deprecating humor about the movie itself is probably helping kill movies even faster.

No way to rate this film for everyone.  Many fans of old Matrix will feel let down.  It's very surreal, not a crowd-pleaser.  It's more about female agency than male agency.  Lots of males will hate that. 
Matrix 4 was a thankless task from the beginning, as Lana W. has said and has Thomas Anderson say in the film. 
Two other films may help the confused relate to this Matrix reboot better.  One is Charlie Kaufman's Adaptation (2002) where breaking the fourth wall between fiction and the viewer's expectations is much of the foreground of the narrative, spectacularly in the third act.  The other is Johnathan Mostow's Terminator 3 (2003) where another director publicly lamented his task: following up and improving on Terminator 2.  
In this context of movies about making movies, I liked Matrix 4 better than I thought I would.  I appreciated Reeves' understated presence.  I liked teh moments of clarity and insight framing the issue of sheeple-followers vs. independent and critical thinking (waking up).  What might have improved this and made it more coherent is more awareness of and attention to two memes:  Healthy democratic socialism as alternative to corporate consumerism neo-feudalism; and, Cultural Creative/Divine Feminine rhetoric. Both these themes haunt the fringes of the film as these really are the likely ways forward culturally and for which new leaders are needed.

Before watching The Matrix Resurrections, my brother compared it with Toy Story 4, a movie that, in my humble opinion, shouldn't exist, because Toy Story 3 is possibly the most perfect ending of a franchise in movies history, the epilogue closes perfectly Woody's and Andy's cycles. Even before its birth, Toy Story 4 looked bitter. The Matrix Revolutions, though, has an ending that allows a future visit to the Matrix universe. And was this new visit satisfying? Well, more or less. It has good ideas and it's easy to immerse yourself in the film because few universes are more sympathetic than the Matrix. Keanu Reeves has his usual charisma, but this time, visually, Neo bothered me a little bit. It was inevitable to compare him with John Wick. Yahya Abdul-Mateen II as Morpheus is a more serious mistake. Okay, Laurence Fishburne didn't accept to repeat his role and I understand the idea of a younger Morpheus, but the character lost his essence, he was never a comic presence. Watching him, I remembered Nick Fury from Captain Marvel. Carrie-Anne Moss works, her relationship with Neo is important to the plot, but her chemistry with Keanu Reeves seems to no longer exist. Jonathan Groff has nowhere near Hugo Weaving's charm as Agent Smith, this iconic character became generic. And not only did Agent Smith become generic, but also the action sequences. The "bullet time" from the 1999 film is better than anything from the 2021 film. Oh, and Neil Patrick Harris has a good role on paper, but he is a pain in the ass, it was hard to abide him because he talks a lot more than he should. The first act is terrible. The universe is good, but the presentation isn't. Besides being hypocritical in a moment where it criticizes its own existence (something Space Jam 2, also from Warner, also did), the movie evokes the other film of the franchise at the same time it looks to rag them. After this long negative text, please don't understand me wrong, this film is a lot better than The Matrix Revolutions. The pace is good, the film, again, has good ideas, is enjoyable and never gets boring. I just missed what made The Matrix be The Matrix. It's a derivative action film, which within that franchise, is frustrating.
Can't they all just get along? 6/10

The Matrix: Resurrections was far better than I anticipated. It deserved results at the box office but it's understandable that people are wary of soft reboots (Terminator Dark Fate was so bad and Star Wars 7 led to the disastrous Last Jedi).

Resurrections has heart and tries to answer questions about its universe. Like what happened after the events of Revolutions. Why the anomaly is useful to the Matrix. Why the peace Neo brought was important (it didn't seem to be in 2003's Revolutions to me).

The first half is the best as it focuses in on Thomas's life as it is without being Neo. A life more ordinary. This theme, something #GenX can relate to, makes this movie work. Is Thomas being who he was meant to be? I kept thinking of Hot Tub Time Machine (the regret of middle age). And Unbreakable (Bruce Willis's characters "sadness in the mornings" while living a life of compromise. 

By the time the movie focuses on Trinity, this theme is glaring. You can relate when she's trying to live her life by asking Neo questions about the Matrix, and her family pulls her away. That's what families do. They often pull you away from your life's work. That's okay because relationships should come first, but you can see why the Catholic Church forbade Priests from marrying. 

I found the ending to be rushed and cartoonish. That doesn't bode well if this franchise is going to continue. But there is mention of "The Suits".. 
However, I give this movie two thumbs up as it stayed with me in my mind the next day, and I want to add it to my BlueRay collection.

Enough reviews going into the gist of why it failed (Well, storyline-wise, to most fans. Seems box office, as expected, it's ok - Currently 50 million under production budget). The thing that really ruffles my feathers is that, as the previous comment, this iteration mostly feels like Wachowski's having a decline in career after spectacular failures (Jupiter Ascending, Cloud Atlas, or being particularly bitter about having Sense8 booted from Netflix seemingly), and accepting to come back to this franchise for the cash grab - Then totally filling the movie with criticism about people returning to movies for a cash grab. 

There'd be *some* sense of profound criticism with good reason (If you followed the whole Netflix versus Wachowski debacle, where they literally started blowing 1 million an episode for Sense8 as a budget on Netflix' dime, flying all over Europe for 5 minutes of shooting a scene and 5 days of drug-induced partying), except for the fact that if you click on the actor list in this 4th Matrix, they *still* recycled all actors from their previous work, like Sense8. I think I see like half the cast of Sense8 in this movie, except for those that spoke out against the Wachowskis, which seem to be blacklisted for life. After blowing up bridges with Netflix (Ending Sense8 with the close-up of a dripping strap-on against their wishes + taking the finale for showing at events without Netflix greenlighting it) and now so blatantly shouting against their parent company in here, it'd be interesting to see who still wants to touch any of the Wachowskis with a ten foot pole :)

The bad: The fight sequences had really jarring cinemaphotography. Too much camera movement fakes action, but this felt almost forced and removed from the source material. And at some points the voice levels were so low in the theater I had a hard time making out what people were saying. And Neo does a lot less physical combat and more magic voodoo stuff which really doesn't lend credit to the originals it just seems like a tacked on super power that can be a get-out-of-jail-free card. And some of the body movements were very... CGI on some characters at some points, like the body mechanics didn't match up, even in a Matrix way. And lastly someone says they played through a video game in one night during the movie and, like, c'mon, that would be such a SHORT GAME if you could crank it out in one night.

The good: Everything else.

This movie is so questionable that almost the entirety of the two and a half hour runtime is spent trying to justify its own existence. It's one of those movies in a franchise that is so bad that it makes you reconsider your entire liking for the other films in the series as well as the talent of the director, Lana Wachowski (half of the Wachowski siblings of original Matrix trilogy fame). *Spoilers ahead* What's so dissapointing about this film is that as imaginitive as the attempts are at explaining the resurrections of both Neo, Trinity, and the Matrix as a whole, it all feels uneccessary. The movie is like a bird who flew into an open cage and the entire time is crying about its imprisonment while the latch is open, no one forced anyone to make this film, so why is it trying to arduously to exist. The meta commentary criticizing the original trilogy while also making the movie seem like more of a direct  critique of social media and the trappings of modern life rings hollow considering this movie is a very part of that machine. It's a movie trapped in the difficult position of reviving a series after so much time that it has to give the audience some excuse to chew on why it should exist at all, but in taking that task on it undoes itself, spending the majority of the time so focused on the question it's almost impossible to not think about it. This is the first sin of many, as the movie also constnatly reuses footage from the trilogy, especially the first Matrix, reminding us why we loved the series in the first place while essentially redoing these scenes only worse. The warddrobe is ludicrous in some futile attempt to modernize the steam-punk/leather/anime fashion of the first films, while Neo is donning a casual sports jacket and jeans look almost the entire film, looking less badass and more ready for a business casual dinner (in some of the movie this outfit makes sense, in his return to the proverbial "matrix" after being "awoken" again it just seems like Neo has given up on the aesthetic of the original films all together. The action might be some of the worst I've seen in recent years, with the original trilogy not only outdoing every action scene here, but also giving each punch, kick, gunshot much more immediacy and higher stakes, while every CGI aided moment of violence here feels lackluster and lacking. In general the movie virtually has no stakes, and feels shackled to the worst elements of the past films without knowing how to appreciate what made them (at leas the first one) truly special. Neo and Trinity might be the only good thing in this movie, as Reeves and Moss still seem to have great chemistry on screen. However other then them the new agent Smith, Morpheus, Neil Patrick Harris' character, and so on are subpar at best, not because they can't act but mostly because the films script is so focused on the mental gymnastics of why, and less on the characters themselves. There's so much to deride, but really you just come away from it feeling sad, old, and rethinking why you ever liked any Matrix film in the first place. Maybe the best aspect of this movie is that it's so trifling that it gives you hope that if someone could make a film as horrendous as this 18 years after the original trilogy ended, maybe we still have time to make better on our lives. Whatever the end result will be, it can't be worse then this.

Agent Smith: "Did you know that the first Matrix was designed to be a perfect human world, where none suffered, where everyone would be happy? It was a disaster. No one would accept the program, entire crops were lost. Some believed we lacked the programming language to describe your perfect world, but I believe that, as a species, human beings define their reality through misery and suffering. The perfect world was a dream that your primitive cerebrum kept trying to wake up from. Which is why the Matrix was redesigned to this". On such a nihilistic premise it was not possible to build anything, it vanified any hypothetical attempt at emancipation as it had already been performed and falsified. The saga was more or less usable and enjoyable on condition of forgetting one of the worst screenplay inconsistencies in the history of cinema or, vice versa, of interpretating it as the demonstration of the truthfulness of the basic assumption. "Matrix 4" is a bogus product, added almost twenty years later without any valid artistic reason: metatextuality avoids the fundamental dilemma, the disquisition on free will is already stale in itself and in any case Lana has the modesty not to take it seriously, the love story between Neo and Trinity had already touched quite another emotional peaks in the mutual resurrection of the first 2 episodes, the criticism of the geek generation who wanted to change the world and instead became its new ruler (and slave) is euphemistically weak, the rejection of a binary logic ("two-valued", Boolean algebra, the Parmenidean and Aristotelian "aut aut: tertium non datur") reiterates the allusion to gender fluidity in cast, actor roles and audience. The rest offers no substantial novelty (CGI, action scenes, characterization of the protagonists). 
(Mauro Lanari)

This might've been a better viewing experience had it actually been 18 years since I last watched a Matrix movie. Seeing it a few days after rewatching the originals unfortunately prevented nostalgia from clouding my judgment. Instead this felt like a completely unnecessary re-tread that, instead of building on the events of the last movie, traced back over the steps of the first where Neo starts out as a nobody again. It would've been cool to see them kind of hit fast-forward on the process & only build on the original trilogy with the third act, but they actually didn't do that & instead just sort of stretched this movie's runtime to cover some of the events of Reloaded instead. Perhaps retrospectively this will be fine if they build on with more installments, but in the first act they had a character say he always doubted Neo was ever really The One; from that moment on it was clear they we were just so hungry for a 4th Matrix that we'd swallow whatever garbage they came up with. The fact that I can't sit here for a moment and think of a different way to do a 4th movie than what they did here is solely evidence that they shouldn't have made this one and isn't at all evidence that they made a good decision here. The worst part was the incredibly low stakes they provided where the entire point of every scene was reuniting Neo with Trinity and nothing else. Their relationship is one of the least-compelling that I've ever seen in any movie, let alone a whole quadrilogy like this. It was the worst aspect of the latter movies of the original trilogy and is enough to ruin this one completely for me. I also disliked the unnecessary recasting they did, but I will say that Keanu is a much better actor when he hides his wooden face with the beard!

The Matrix Resurrections - 8.5/10. Lana Wachowski returns to the directors chair and returns the beloved (and well discussed) The Matrix series back to the big screen! And though Resurrections acts as a step up from the previous two instalments (the somewhat underrated The Matrix Reloaded and the disappointing The Matrix Revolutions), its still not entirely on the level of the original. But oh does it aim high! A wonderfully meta film which reboots the franchise in an interesting way, we find out that Neo and Trinity have been brought back from the dead and reentered into the Matrix. When Neo begins to have visions of his past, the powers that be in the "real" world work their hardest to push down his awakening. In the process, a new group of awakened soldiers try to get the rebooted Neo to join the new fight against the machines! A superbly thought out film is a little bit let down by some decisions here and there, this sequel is definitely fun and quite the mind tingler as well! The one thing I enjoy the most about this franchise is that its cerebral. Along with the great action comes some well thought out meta philosophical/religious allegories that make the action more meaningful. The movie acts as a commentary on the state of modern day summer blockbusters as well! Its fun to see Keanu Reeves and Carrie Anne Moss back in their iconic roles! They carry the movie above with their wonderful chemistry and feel for the action. The disappointing factor is the recasting of Morpheus and Agent Smith. Both Yahya Abdul Mateenii and Jonathan Groff are fine in their performances, but its a little bit of a bummer to not have Laurence Fishburne and Hugo Weaving back! Other than that, the rest of the cast is fine! Its also cool how the movie reuses footage from the original trilogy often throughout the film! Its a nice way to help remind the audience and add a sense of "deja-vu" for Neo during the process of reacquainting with the Matrix. Making the story be based around game development was also a nice touch! It does get a little messy in thought near the third quarter, but other than that, the movie is a solid return for a great franchise!
In fact, I think it's not bad, but the audience who haven't seen the previous trilogy will feel a little confused when they watch this one.

Action is largely boring despite the high-budget CGI. Plot is nearly nonsensical with a bit of identity politics and romance thrown in to pass the Hollywood rubric. Reminds me of the Disney Star Wars films - all the glitz and painfully self-conscious virtue signalling, none of the thoughtful philosophy, sci-fi, or world crafting. If this was the Wachowski's attempt to give a middle finger to Warner Bros for forcing their hand with the threat of making the movie without them, then mission accomplished. However it also ends up being a perhaps unintentional middle finger to the audience that wanted to see another glimpse into the world the first Matrix film revealed, which none since has successfully revisited. In a time where virtual reality, AI, and robotics are taking baby steps, and millions fear for automation of their jobs while truth and reality are bent like play things for the rich and powerful, this seems like a missed opportunity to seize the zeitgeist and deliver something meaningful about the world we are building. A matrix prequel, taking place during the Second Renaissance where machine served man until they revolted, or even earlier when man was first freed from nearly all labor by machines, would have been far more prescient and sincere.

That is until Neo wakes the hell up and starts giving us the movie we've waited the best part of 20 years for. Alas.

The premise posed more questions than it answered and the plot doesn't make too much sense, even in the world of the Matrix (or the Matrix in the Matrix).  I left the cinema feeling like it was a shame they did this and that it didn't REALLY need to be made, for all the things it "added" to the story.

The newer elements like "transmorphic" programmes were a bit too far for me. As for the "cuddly sentinels" they were a bit corny and more "Free Willy" than the hi-tech AI entities they're supposed to be - you get the impression this will be a line of toys. 

The movie missed several opportunities; to explore the layers of the matrix and its origins  a bit more; explain the fate of the architect properly; a credible story for Iio (Zion's replacement); why Neo hadn't aged (that much) in 60 years; why there was a 60 year gap in the first place; How Agent Smith got reincarnated and why he was placed next to Neo to not do anything to him given his hatred for him.

This is a really good move, just not a great Matrix movie, although it isn't as bad as Matrix Revolutions, so I guess there's that.
