An improvement from the previous film but not a great improvement. At least it felt somewhat like a Matrix film in concept but not visually. I don't mean the visuals are bad. The visual effects look good and so does the cinematography but it's missing that iconic green tint. This is obviously a minor issue but it impacts the film a lot. The green tint is iconic to the trilogy and it not being here makes the film feel like it's lacking something. A lot of this film feels like it's lacking. The story is really weak and contrived and it's meta commentary is awful. It's possible to do meta commentary on your own films/genre right, look to the Scream films for that, but it's awful here. They make fun of the tropes but then do the exact same thing without a hint of irony. It feels like they forgot there was meta commentary to this film. It's my biggest issue with this film and it really drags it down. Some of the action doesn't necessarily suck but it isn't great either. It's hard to tell what is going on and it's filmed in such a bland way. The performances are fine. Keanu Reeves is being Keanu Reeves and Carrie-Ann Moss is fine. Neil Patrick Harris and Jonathan Groff are standouts but I take issue with their characters. Groff plays Hugo Weaving's role from the original films but he just kinda starts being Agent Smith. There isn't any build up prior and he just becomes him. The issue I have with Neil Patrick Harris's character is due to his presentation on screen. They lower the frame rate whenever he is on screen and it looks awful. They lower the frame rate a lot in this movie and it never looks good. This film really didn't need to have been made but at least it has some sort of message which is more than I can say for Revolutions. I probably would recommend passing on this movie and just watching the original again.

The Matrix Resurrections is the latest installment in the mind-boggling franchise. It revisits our beloved characters in what feels like a reboot -- because the main leads are back in the Matrix and somehow entangled by its complex world. Because this new installment happens several years after the last movie, it introduces a new set of  characters, some of which I like. I like Bugs because of her charm and feisty spirit. I also absolutely love Neil Patrick Harris as one of the new villains, because he's such a fine actor.  Although I'm glad that they still got the original actors like Keanu Reeves and Carrie-Anne Moss, I honestly felt sad that Laurence Fishburne and Hugo Weaving didn't reprise their roles. It was fine to see a new actor as Morpheus, but it felt really odd to see Agent Smith being played by another actor. The movie still has excellent visual effects. The action somewhat lacks the usual kung fu style fights from the previous movies. And the use of "bullet time", which made the previous movies such hits, are too few in this new one. The movie also lacks the wit, charm and originality of the first Matrix movie. Also, some of the flashbacks were too repetitive and unnecessary. Overall, it's still entertaining, albeit to a lesser degree.

I finally managed to watch Matrix 4 (it was always too crowded for my taste till today). Right from the start one realizes that this new edition is made in a way to facilitate even a newcomer into the Matrix universe, but I'd say it's a ridiculous commercial attempt. Nobody can actually understand M4 without having seen all of the former ones. Thus said I am sure that anybody who loved the original trilogy will also enjoy this very improbable but still excellently scripted new edition and obvious start to a new set of movies. The difficult idea of restarting the obviously finished story of Matrix was brilliantly executed through a mishmash of flashbacks and new ideas. I have to admit that I shortly dozed off three times around the two hour mark (and that even though I watched it in the afternoon) as, right in the lane of the first three movies of the franchise, there is often enough too much philosophical blabber in dark and somber places which surely bores to a certain extent. But still there is enough action around to keep one entertained, some old style, some very cool new gimmicks. All in all 140 minutes of a cool movie which could have better been packed within 100-110 minutes. 7 1/2 of 10 points.

However, when it has to be a Matrix movie, it's not the best Matrix movie. The world building questions they answer aren't enough to satisfy me, and while the action is okay there isn't any scene that blew me away like the other films. That said the performances here are better than any of the other films, and it looks great. If there had to be a Matrix 4, this is a solid enough one.

It is a film that tries to show itself as innovative, making itself difficult to understand, but without success, since it does not propose something different from what has already been seen in past installments, such as the concept of a simulated reality in which humanity lives, created by intelligent machines, and from which the protagonist Neo wakes up to fight the machines, again. In a few words, the film presents us with the same plot of Matrix 1, only after 60 years. 
The film presents scenes such as the reconstruction of Morpheus from Neo's memories of the events that occurred in the Matrix 1, 2, and 3 movies, which are stored inside a video game which he himself programs while living in the original Matrix. To do this, a girl from the real world named Bugs enters the video game created by Neo (forgive the redundancy) to unplug digital Morpheus from that software, from there send him to the Matrix, and from there release him into the real world through a humanoid body made of metal balls, pesto that does not possess a human body like the original Morpheus. This is an example of the kind of scenes that make the film difficult to understand and that do not add anything relevant to the story. 
In the film we also see absurd scenes such as the resurrection of Trinity, which was already practically dead in Matrix 3, but in this one we are told that her body was recovered by the machines, rebuilt and miraculously returned to life to be re-entered to the Matrix with Neo, a situation that makes no sense since they are a great danger to the existence of the Matrix and the machines. The most logical thing is that they would have left Trinity and Neo to die to eliminate their remaining enemies. 
As a fan of the original trilogy, I expected the directors to philosophically innovate the story in this film, since the most modern physics theories explore time travel, multiverses, extra dimensions, and multilayers of computer simulated reality, I think that only it was enough for them to look at those theories and add some of that to the movie to make it more interesting. But no, they stayed exploring the same two layers of reality, that is, the Matrix and the real world. As a curious fact, in Matrix 3 Neo has super powers in reality and can see the world as made of light, that would explain why the Matrix would be multilayered, and even the video game created by Neo could be considered one more layer of the Matrix, at least the directors would have explored these multilayers in depth to cause an impact on the viewer, but they just did more of the same.

A film that wants to criticize modern cinema that is almost entirely based on rebuts, on nostalgia for the old years.  There are few directors who bring innovative films into the room (Nolan, Tarantino ...) The director of the Matrix in the first part of the film wants to underline these elements by re-proposing a plot already seen less compelling.  The first act is the one I appreciated the most.  the problem is the last act, in which a series of very badly managed fights take place.  This film is not groundbreaking from a plot point of view, but it stands out as a critic from the director.  The scene after the credits confirms this fact.

I'm sorry to report that the new Matrix is shockingly bad. Like straight cringe, scene one. It's basically a typical beat-for-beat retread/soft reboot of the original Matrix, but it's also both hyper-self-aware and in deep denial that that's what it is, so it has a ton of cringey self-aware dialogue peppered throughout to try to disguise that fact. Like "look, we know that this is what this looks like, but we're aware of that so trust us, it's actually much DEEPER." But it's not, it's just a lame retelling of a much better older movie. By pointing out its own shallowness, the film thinks it can rise above what it is, but it ends up just drawing attention to that fact even more. There's also a ton of awkward dialogue and random clips referencing the original film, just constantly reminding you that you're watching an inferior version. The movie feels like a clip show for the original trilogy more than an actual film itself at times. On top of that the action is weak (possibly this film's greatest sin), even going so far as to make inferior, far more choppily-edited recreations of much better, more iconic action scenes from the original. And finally, the weird replacements for original characters (I won't spoil who) do not remotely justify why they have taken over from the iconic original actors. This film is like The Force Awakens, but without even the fun action scenes, brisk pacing, or likable new characters to keep it entertaining. I wasn't expecting a masterpiece, but this ended up being far worse than I expected.  A very disappointing film.

There is a lot to say about 'The Matrix Resurrections'. First off, it was fine. Not exactly what I'd wished it to be. It could have been more or less but then again; we didn't ask for this to be made. Thankfully, I enjoyed this a bit more than I expected with all the mixed reviews and it offers a fairly natural progression of the story after the extravagant but hollow conclusion of the original trilogy, "Revolutions". In despite of that, this falls into the problems of the sequels with their storytelling: being dense and clunky stuffed with intriguing ideas but struggling to give us an array of characters and scenarios to care about. With this surprising installment, it suffers from missing elements and a strange lack in execution with what made the Matrix so special. Here are a few of the things that are sorely missing from this entry: Joel Silver, Lilly Wachowski, Bill Pope & Yuen Woo-ping. I can't say I know everything there is about a movie producers' job other than financing movie projects and making sure every facet of the productions run smoothly. Joel Silver was an exec on the original trilogy and his legendary filmography speaks for itself. He evidently didn't return to produce "Resurrections", and it makes me wonder how differently the story would have turned out under his watch. I'm glad that Lana Wachowski came back to make another Matrix movie, whether her vision had been marinating all these years or her hand was forced to dish out another "Matrix" film by the studio. But the one big thing that the marketing champaign keep in secrecy (only hinting at it a week before release) is just how full-blown meta the story was going to be. 


It is quite a creative "choice" to acknowledge storylines, characters, plot points, quoted lines, and even recreating many shots from the original trilogy the way that they do in this sequel, and it is a major point of contention for most of the fans; Lingering so heavily on the familiar instead of moving forward brazenly into the unknown, all while answering all the questions as to how/why Neo & Trinity are back and how the worlds of machines & men have changed since their harrowing events of "Revolutions". Most of the questions are answered, though with plodding exposition and awkward "lightness" which often kills much of the momentum and stakes of the narrative. There is a disjointed struggle with making either the meta-commentary of today's media consumed society, a snarky slap at the business of Hollywood blockbusters or a potentially compelling story arc of Neo rediscovering himself stick its landing. There are a lot of cool ideas that this film touches on (including a civil war among the Machines and evolution of the human's relation with Sentients). Unfortunately, the movie leans more into the standard fare of the previous films than truly embracing these ideas for its own benefit. Above anything else, I find the love story of Neo & Trinity perhaps the most satisfying storyline here and their scenes together are fun to watch, I can't say I am a fan of these "discount" variants of Morpheus and Agent Smith. Yahya Abdul-Mateen II is fine but, even though he doesn't have to imitate Laurence Fishburne's iconic role, his lack of charisma by comparison is unmistakable. Jonathan Groff arguably makes his part a bit his own as "Smith" but how he utilized into the narrative is wonky at best and doesn't add much menace like Hugo Weaving did in his own sleep! Some of the other new additions of the cast fare better. Jessica Henwick gets a lot of screentime as Bugs, and she carries it well. Although I can't quite get past his "How I Met Your Mother" image, Neil Patrick Harris is having some fun as "The Analyst". 


Oddly enough, the weakest aspect of the movie is the action. The set-pieces are fine at best but hardly memorable and not nearly as stylized as it was with the original trilogy. This is flat-out disappointing given how one of the biggest achievements of the original and parts of the sequels is the amazing action; the other being the Visual effects, which are most reliable part of 'Resurrections" but even some of the effects get a bit dodgy.  With Lana directing all the action scenes herself (no second-unit director, mind you) and the absence of her sister Lilly Wachowski as co-director, it makes me believe the Lana probably had the handle on story/character while Lilly may have helped refine the staging of the set-pieces with the originals. But what's more of a detriment to this movie is that the absence of the cinematographer and stunt choreographer of the original trilogy: Bill Pope & Yuen Woo-ping. Pope captured the fights and chase sequences pf the original trilogy with such fluidity and robust shot composition that gave the visuals a graphic novel flair. Woo-ping's kung fu choreography was fast & furious, landing every punch or kick with endless style or heft. In 'Resurrection", the action consist mostly of shootouts, a couple chases and a lack of kung-fu, all plainly framed and hectically edited, almost resorting to "shaky-cam" in some instances. When I was moderately gripped with the story on my first viewing, the action sequences actually took me out of the experience! Not to put any blame on Oscar-winning DP John Toll, who was credited as cinematographer for much of the filming but left the project for personal reasons and Wachowski's long-time camera operator, Daniele Massacessi, took over. This is the first Matrix movie shot entirely digital; the Matrix itself sans the off-set green tint for a crystal-clear image that makes it looks more sterile than gritty, which is fitting for the version of the program in the context of this story but takes away the grit away from the action scenes. I have mixed feelings about how they expand on the concept of "Bullet-Time here but the sequence in question is more visually creative than all the generic shoot-outs and sloppy fisticuffs. The finale fares a bit better but nothing like as jaw-dropping as the third act of the first film was.


Then, the movie ends pretty abruptly; giving that feeling like this is the film you just watch so you can watch the next and hopefully better movie. Some have compared this movie to "Star Wars: The Last Jedi" and that can understandable because of how wildly divisive "Resurrections" turned out to be critically and both movies deconstruct their respective franchises. But unlike "The Last Jedi", where its subversive turns, strong character arcs and emotional heft made me feel utterly enthralled and inspired in that beloved cinematic realm, "Resurrections" ended up in the opposite direction and evocated an indifferent response. Ultimately, this latest plugin doesn't quite capture the impact or ingenuity of the original. Despite its many flaws, I sort of see this as a expanded epilogue or coda that manages to give a more serviceable end to a once ground-breaking, now tiresome film series than the sour anti-climax of "Revolutions" - 6/10 (C+)

Trinity rises to power in a way that female characters were not allowed to before. And even if you don't want to see the patriarchy literally fall apart - this is easily one of the best (and excellently shot) action films of the last 30 years.

WIthout giving anything away, I can say strongly, that the first hour was not only a bore - it was angering. It is TALKING, and on the level of 13 year old philosophy. My gawd it's so bad. Now, add in nearly 9 references to the blue or red pill in that first hour, take away all but two measly special effects that you've seen before (correct NOTHING NEW in the way of ANY MATRIX universe - and you'll have seen a groundbreaking franchise get dumped on by the Guiness book of world records largest turd of dialogue and mood for dummies. The guy dropping the turd? One of the WIchowskis herself. As if to be so unaware of what made the originals popular and lacking the skill to produce something new, let alone something that isn't a total soapy trope and full of self-love and audience numbness from the utter shock it could be THIS BAD! To give an example, I went in with expectations it was going to be bad - with the hope (and usual correct assumption) that this outlook will still give me some satisfaction for lowered expectations. ALAS, however, it is one of the very few times in thousands of movies I've watched, where this actually didn't work. You'd have to go in with mood of seeing the worst movie of all time and prepare for it to maybe even extract one inkling of satisfaction from it - and that is me being generous - I actually think there is no way to watch this and have a greater than 0.5 stars. Worse still - I am surprised by critics reviews constantly - they live in their own world and like what they like, they don't represent me, who does the same thing without getting paid for it.. I would love to go on and relate it to other movies and moods - and I could do so for likely hours upon hours for this films first 60 minutes alone.

SO THE SHORT VERSION: do not buy, do not rent, don't watch a trailer, block it from coming up in your newsfeeds, and just tell yourself now to completely skip it, or if you must, then make sure you follow the famous 10 minute rule of show watching-- if the movie doesn't draw you into it in the first 10 minutes, it will be a stinker, and no amount of time beyond that shall be acceptable, for this type of movie will yank another hour of your life leaving you slightly more angry as before, and instead of going to see some action-ish movie with crap thrown all around it. I say this to save you, the reader, and slam the series of money lenders that thought it'd be fun to waste their dollars on an insane project that should still be in tightening up the script (rather, throwing it away and getting someone to write an interesting one. I haven't been this disappointed with a sequel in as long as I can remember. While their are good parts to the production, particularly in effects and post production elements, the good parts weren't ground breaking or pushing the industry with innovation in the way that the earlier movies did. 

As for the rest - the plot was thin, unimaginable and for the most part predictable, even making fun of itself during the first act. The entire movie felted forced, which might be the case when the movie actually includes the line, "Our beloved parent company, Warner Bros, has decided to make a sequel to the trilogy". At times, it truly felt like that may be the only reason for the movies existence. The plot did not further the overall story arch in any big meaningful way, the deep dive into philosophy was gone, and all we were left with was a movie that relied on heavy-handed slapping's of nostalgia to crawl its way through to the end. 

The previously well picked soundtrack and crafted orchestration that helped build the movies tension and feel are replaced with a bland mediocre effort. The acting was poor for the calibre of cast they signed on board and the choreography was extremely poor in franchise that had previously pushed the boundaries and dominated the film world. For an action franchise that previously brought some iconic gun battles our main character doesn't even pick up a single gun in this movie, and compared to previous iterations his superpowers are now limited to holding his hands in the air. He does, once attempt to fly - which results in him leaping about 1 foot from the ground in a poor attempt at humour.

The issue is this - If your not a huge fan of the old movies you may like this, but then the nostalgia is so heavy that you probably won't. If you were a huge Matrix fan, this movies is so far away from the original trilogy that you'll slowly begin to hate it as it plays out in front of you. There's no target audience that this movie finds the right balance for in any large part and as a huge Matrix fan myself, while i'l still watch the trilogy this entry is a terminator 3 - we'll all just pretend its not part of the set.

After 18 years, Neo is back: a bit older, a bit slower, but still The One. With only one of the Wachowskis, Lana, at the helm, the film still manages to capture the look and feel of the original trilogy. The story has several extra layers and is therefore even more confusing, yet not unbearably so. A few of the original actors, namely Keanu Reeves, Carrie-Anne Moss, and Jada Pinkett Smith, lead a cast of younger ones. Of those, particularly Star Wars: The Force Awakens' Jessica Henwick stands out, right next to Starship Troopers' (not so young) Neil Patrick Harris.

edit: Another re-watch, since there is nothing new out there. The second time around was still a lot of fun and gave me a better understanding of the new, machine characters on the rebel side, particularly the night fury that helps free Trinity. Oh, and I had more time to admire the sunglasses. Just as in the original trilogy, the shades (and rebel outfits when inside the matrix) are just awesome!

December 22, 2021

Does Neo control the Matrix or is it the Matrix that controls Neo? That's just one of the questions we're asking ourselves as "The Matrix Resurrections" starts to unravel. Others may include: Didn't Neo and Trinity die at the end of "The Matrix Revolutions"? If so, how are they alive now? Why is Morpheus a younger version of himself, not to mention played by a different actor, compared to the other major characters? With so many scene and dialogue parallels between "Resurrections" and the original "Matrix," especially at the beginning, is the former simply regurgitating the latter?

To its credit, "Resurrections" eventually answers all these questions and more, and it does so in a mostly satisfactory and credible way (or at least as credible as any "Matrix" film can). One quality the heavy screenplay for "Resurrections" doesn't lack is exposition and it goes out of its way to clearly, if laboriously, explain why things are the way they are in the latest Matrix universe. It expounds so much, in fact, that even "Matrix" novices may be able to walk into this fourth installment of the once wildly popular franchise and understand what's happening. What's more is that no matter how familiar one is with either "The Matrix" films, comic books, novels, or video games, "Resurrections" keeps us engaged and wanting to understand more. And yet, by the end, no matter how many satisfying answers and payoffs the film provides, we're not quite sure it was worth our time, and we question its necessity.

After the disappointing and much maligned "Revolutions," you might be wondering if "Resurrections" was just a way for the studio and filmmakers to make amends. On the contrary, they take this new chapter seriously and perform their due diligence in terms of looking at the Matrix universe from a fresh angle. Writer-director Lana Wachowski, who, with her sister Lilly, wrote and helmed the original trilogy, doesn't mail anything in here, but instead makes the setup for "Resurrections" surprisingly clever and interesting.
 
In the film, six decades have passed since the events of "Revolutions," and we learn the ceasefire Neo (Keanu Reeves) negotiated with the CPU of the machines has ended. You'll recall the underlying premise of "The Matrix" was that artificially intelligent machines took over the planet and essentially turned humans into dormant batteries, relegating their bodies to lie motionless in pods filled with pink goo as their minds were plugged in and distracted by the Matrix, a simulated reality of Earth that was monitored by agents. Humans in the Matrix live blindly and oblivious to the harsh truth that they are slaves, and the world is, in fact, an ashen wasteland, rife with pollution, gray skies, and dilapidated cities.

With peace between humans and machines now dissolved (after the machines learned they couldn't sustain themselves without humans' bioelectric energy powering them), the dystopia we saw in the original "Matrix" films has been reinstated. But just as the machines have regained power and control, a group of determined Resistance fighters have maintained hope that Neo is still "The One," or savior, who can bring about everlasting balance and harmony, as the prophecy says.

One of these Resistance fighters is the fresh-faced Bugs (Jessica Henwick), who, with her operator Seq (Toby Onwumere), discovers a modal within the Matrix that is running old code in a continuous loop. The code renders scenes suspiciously like the classic opening sequence of the original "Matrix," of which Bugs knows the history. It is in this modal that Bugs also finds a young version of Morpheus (Yahya Abdul-Mateen II), or rather, a programmed version of him. 

Bug extrapolates that this anomalous modal could only mean one thing: Neo, or some remnant of him, still exists. And, as it turns out, a middle-aged Thomas Anderson (Neo's alternate identity) is indeed "alive" and well and living in the Matrix, and he's once again a programmer, although a much more respected one because this time around he's the brains behind a highly lauded and successful video game called, wouldn't you know, "The Matrix." 

Yes, "Mr. Anderson," as his business partner Smith (Jonathan Groff) calls him, works for a software company called Deus Machina and he's designed and developed a game trilogy that mirrors "The Matrix" movie trilogy. This aspect of the plot naturally makes for some snappy, elbow-nudging meta as Neo's cohorts, including the obnoxious Jude (Andrew Lewis Caldwell), all talk "Matrix," opining on the series' virtues, shortcomings, deeper meanings, influence on pop culture, etc. The movie, as we're watching it, has just enough self-awareness and winks to the camera without going overboard and becoming smug or exhausting. 

Fortunately, the film's self-analysis serves a purpose beyond just making it cute and savvy. The constant discussion and insights into "The Matrix" perpetuate Thomas' beliefs that he didn't just dream up the idea for the game randomly or through luck, but that it's somehow an extension of his true self and reflects his real-life memories. But how can that be? Isn't he currently living his one and only real life?

This cognitive dissonance eats away at Thomas, and despite being a popular game designer, he's a tortured individual—lonely, anxious, and anti-social. The little happiness he does feel comes from his frequenting a coffee shop and observing a woman from afar named Tiffany (Carrie-Anne Moss), although we know her as Trinity. She's always there with her kids and husband, and without knowing exactly why, Thomas senses a deep connection to her, and when they finally meet, she feels it too.

At the same time, Thomas is haunted by trippy visions and intense moments of déjà vu, which he relates to his psychiatrist (Neil Patrick Harris), but his doctor insists his nightmares and dark thoughts are merely the result of irrational triggers and that Thomas should just keep taking the blue pills he's been prescribed to keep his mind at ease. Of course, "Matrix" veterans know it is the blue pill, versus the red one, that prevents him from thinking clearly and seeing the world for what it really is. When Thomas simply can't take it anymore, and the sites of black cats and mirrors drive him to the point of near mania, he feels he has no choice but to end things by jumping off a building. 

That's where Bugs and company come in, and in typical "Matrix"-style, she and her crew rescue Neo's physical body and introduce him to the real world—again. From here, what transpires is not too far removed from the trajectory of the original "Matrix": Neo "wakes up" and becomes acquainted with flesh and blood humans; he's informed about dire state of the world and learns what happened over the past 60 years, which includes the beloved city of Zion getting destroyed and a new city, IO, being founded by Niobe (a heavily made up Jada Pinkett Smith, reprising her role from the last two films) and other survivors; and Neo and his fellow Resistance fighters embarking on a rescue mission, this time to save Trinity. Naturally, revved up shootouts, car and motorcycle chase sequence, and gravity-defying, bullet time right scenes ensure.

Of course, there are many more details, updates, and new (as well as old) characters to speak of, which I won't reveal, and all these hold our attention and keep "The Matrix Resurrections" moving at a solid pace. Despite its too long runtime (it clocks in at just under two and a half hours), the plot is always interesting, the visuals are consistently sharp and striking, and the special effects are once again state of the art. Plus, there are a few unexpected plot twists and moments of witty humor that catch us off guard, such as when Neo responds to the question of whether he can still fly.

What's also surprising is how much we come to genuinely care about the human characters and their yearning for love and freedom. Wachowski develops them beyond just slick-looking, cartoonish people donning black trench coats and cool sunglasses. The movie pauses enough and gives the characters enough one-on-one screen time to have real conversations about what they think and desire, especially Neo and Trinity, whose relationship takes on greater meaning than before, perhaps because we see shots of their younger selves from the original trilogy intercut with their present ones, which allows us to gain a sense of their history. This sincere human element is something we don't expect from a "Matrix" movie.

And yet, with all this said, as impressed as we may be by the quality and effort put into this third sequel, and as much as it doesn't come across merely as a hollow cash grab, "The Matrix Resurrections" ultimately lacks spark. It's rhythmic and thoughtful, sure, but it's also too slow and the energy level never spikes beyond a certain threshold to make us feel excited or put us in a state of awe and/or eager anticipation the way the other films in the series did (or any good film does). The action sequences, as well produced and convincing as they are, are more admirable than entertaining. And as much as they give to it, the filmmakers and returning cast members seem tired. We sense their dedication but not their enthusiasm. It's as if a part of them is always asking, "Wait, why are we making this again?" I'm not sure they know, and their perceived uncertainty affects us, because it leads us to ask, "Wait, why are watching this again?"

Perhaps this was inevitable, given the amount of time that has passed between the original "Matrix" trilogy and "Resurrections." As franchises age, they simply can't have the same impact they once had, and because "Resurrections" doesn't ignite us to the point where we feel we must keep watching it, I can't quite recommend it. It does hold viewers, but it's not essential viewing. If there's going to be a "Matrix 5," I would suggest it be driven by a whole new set of characters struggling with a conflict other than human versus machine. I don't know what the story could be, but if the plan is to keep this franchise going, I think it needs to break away from what it's already done and the people it already knows. As Morpheus once said, it needs to "let it all go." Maybe then, "The Matrix" series can leap into territory and once again make us say, "Whoa."

This movie is a lot like MGS2, it is a movie sequel that question the existence of sequels itself, it is a critique from the movie creator's point of view that asks the viewer why does he want a sequel? Does he wants the story to continue? Or does he want exactly the same thing as the first movie? And if the expectations of the viewer are more inclined to the second question, then why does he want a sequel when he could just watch the original again, because it happens people go to the movies to see sequels and then they do not like it when the sequel is different from the original, they expect the same movie, it's just genius, I loved it and was totally worth watching it in the movie theater. I recommend everyone to go see this movie 100%>

I know that this installment was not the greatest and fell short of what expectations were. But here is where is actually succeeds. Even back in 2003 when Matrix: Reloaded and Revolutions came out, we didn't even have social media apps and smart technology. Flip phones were still still in have demand. Cell phones were still pretty fresh in the commodities category back then. Laptops and computers and all technology has evolved since the original trilogy came out. It incorporated all of that into the world of the Matrix franchise. It wasn't an easy task. I think Lana Wachowski without her sister Lily did a good job by herself. The way they brought both Neo and Trinity back was very well done and creative. I thought that they were going the path of cloning half way through the film since Neo couldn't use his full power. The retcon that they together are the ones does on further reflection make sense. While a lot of this film has some feeling of it being a rehash of the original and to some degree it is but it does really differ and scores huge continuing the story. That's the big thing here, it's not a reboot it's a continuation. It also showed us that in timeline within the 60 years since the third film that there has been heavy repercussions and more questions left unanswered and more questions now asked. I would also like to add that if it hadn't come out around the same time as Spider-Man: No Way Home that Box office-wise it would have done spectacularly. Not to take away from Spider-Man, that film was flat out textbook spectacular and deserves all of its attention. I think that it will probably be some time again before we see another Matrix film but I hope that we do. Because again while it's not a perfect film like the the others were, it showed a lot of potential.
I give as many stars as I game because it honestly deserves it. Why? Because critics all and all can be harsh and not enjoy a film for enjoyments sake. It's not a bad film. A bad film in my book would be a solid 20% critics and audiences. That's not the case here.

The Matrix Resurrections was not half as good as I'd hoped. The plot just didn't have any substance, really, and Neo's abilities were lackluster compared to the first 3 movies. Plot spoiler ahead...

It seemed the entire movie focused only on getting Trinity out of the goo. There just wasn't much more substance to it than that. Even Neil Patrick Harris's role as Thomas Anderson's counselor was secondary and did little to make the movie exciting. I also hated the fact that Morpheus was not played by the original actor. I also didn't understand why Neo's powers had been so seriously impacted. I mean, I get it that he was in the goo for a very long time, but so was Trinity, and she came out of the goo a badass while Neo was a sad shell of himself. And speaking of time, Neo appeared as an old man to other people, but Trinity did not appear to have aged, and she was arguably in the goo for the same amount of time. So...what's up with that?

Anyway, I just didn't see the need to bring this franchise back in this way. Where are the real enemies, the machines behind the Matrix? If this movie would have gone in a different direction, such as Neo, Trinity and the Zion crew taking down the Matrix for good instead, that would have been awesome. Maybe they've got that planned for another sequel. But I don't know if I will watch it, after watching Resurrections. If they make another sequel, can they at least turn Neo back into the badass he was and give the movie a more exciting threat to eliminate?

To be honest, "The Matrix Resurrections" should be studied as a spectacular example of how to write an entire 2 hours movie without having delivered anything important in the end, which is actually the function of a movie trailer.

Talking about the movie trailer, at first you can even forgive the abuse of Jefferson Airplane's "White Rabbit" track in yet another pseudo-philosophical movie -- I mean, let's not be so picky. It's Matrix. But the whole story is already condensed there - it's about the preparation (resurrecting Neo and Trinity) to fight within a very different matrix universe, which takes place after the context of the first movies. 

That premisse is ok and there's interesting news actually. But everything in the movie happens as if something important is about to happen, until the movie ends. I mean, there is no solution presented for any of the great issues raised. It's just a parade of performances. It's so bizarrely bad that it seems the "action" scenes themselves don't serve as part of the main plot story, until you get that the preparation itself is the main plot.

Curious to think that Neo's character within the Matrix illusion is now a famous video game producer. As a film The Matrix Resurrections almost replicates the critical failure of a highly anticipated video game called "Cyberpunk 2077", to which Keanu Reeves sold his image rights, and which was released a lot more flawed than this.

Bottom line about blockbusters, publicity blue pill will always win.

Matrix: resurrection … "Following the white rabbit down the hole of nostalgia and disappointment"
Warning: If you are a matrix hard core fan, who still remembers by heart the trilogy's storyline, reciting it down to verbatim wordings of the dialogue and spent days debating meanings, hidden theories, futuristic ideas as well as visionary action scenes, then i am sorry to tell you that the so called 4th installment is definitely NOT for you. 
There was a reason why the original story ended in the trilogy. Reason is simple; the story concluded with the 3rd installation (Matrix:Revolutions), as per the Washowski's own words. We should have noticed the warning signs when one of the Washowskis, refused to share in this movie and preferred to have nothing to do with their only memorable cinematic creation! Clearly Warner Bros had a different opinion and wanted to continue milking the success of the Matrix-verse till the very last penny, even if it was on the expense of millions of fans worldwide who hold the trilogy so dear.
Sitting in theatre waiting for the movie to begin gave me goosebumps. It felt like being in a time capsule going back in time. To my surprise, when the movie started, it literally felt so. I  went back in time to the old movies but time froze there. Resurrection takes everything you loved about the Matrix trilogy and turns it into a bad joke.
The movie opens with a remake of the famous Trinity escape scene from the "the Matrix" then goes on a series of flashbacks….. A LOT of them. For the first hour, we get actual scenes from the original trilogy embedded in the new installation. It felt more like a documentary for a whole hour and sarcastically enough with documentary style comments from the current movie actors on the previous scenes :(((
The only significant new thing you could identify in that movie is Aging. Everyone aged significantly, and seems that there were no attempts from the movie makers to conceal this fact. Keanu Reeves (Neo) aged and metamorphosed into John Wick. Yes! you didn't misread this. For some reason, Keanu reeves looks have nothing to do with the Matrix's Neo but feel more as if he just left the shooting set of John Wick and walked across the street into the Matrix resurrection studio!!!! The only difference between Neo and John Wick in this movie is that Neo did not carry any guns. Wait what?!!!  Yes, thoughout the movie, he didn't bear any firearms. Instead, NEO relied on his vanishing charisma, innocent loving eye look, and some remnants of the old Kung-fu he once learned in a simulation program (revise "the Matrix" if you didn't see it) that he became obviously very slow at compared to previous movies. Trinity (Carrie Anne Moss) aged, paled, slowed, married with 2 kids, yet continues to rely on her loving eye looks to Neo. Somehow Matrix developed into a Titanic love story. 
The gruesome plot line is based on the strong love connection between Neo and Trinity that has the power to tear the Matrix apart if they united. The new world built by the creepy analyst (Neil Patrik Harris) is based on keeping the love birds separated to harness their energy and in the same time stop them from re-uniting to avoid destroying the Matrix perfect weave.
"Matrix Resurrections" depicts NEO trapped in a new matrix as a virtual reality games developer who ironically developed a game called the Matrix that has grown into 3 universally famous parts. Of course despite being rich, successful and famous, Neo continued  to have his doubts about his reality and feelings that something is wrong (familiar?! ;)). Ironically, the whole world now is just a video game and every body is hooked. Sounds very real to me.
The movie mocks itself harshly from the beginning till the Marvel-style cartoonish post-credits scene. Marvel has infested this era's movies with its post-credits scene routine. Here, we get this supposedly funny scene showing Neo's video game developing team brain-storming about the reasons behind the popularity of the Matrix.
We get a fresh Agent smith (Johnathan Groff),  Neo's nemesis, a newer younger actor who did good to be fair, but the shoes he had to fill (Hugo Weaving original Smith) are too big for him, Nice try though.
The New Morpheus (Yahya Abdul-Mateen) did his best to get out of the mantle of  Laurence Fishburne (original Morpheus) however he takes the route of mockery and bashes his predecessor's scenes starting with infamous blue/Red pill scene, saying "i should be more dramatic as he was, right" then exodes in a manic laughter!!
Priyanka Chopra, the movie could survive without her. Didn't see any reason for her being here except for the big bucks for both herself and Warner Bros. 
Personally, i felt awful seeing how Resurrection reduced the wise and powerful french mastermind, the Merovingian (Lambert Wilson) from "the Matrix:Reloaded" into a vagabond creepy purged program that kept screaming and ranting in french for over 3 useless minutes before being blown away.
Action and effects are so mind boggling terrible.  Music score is definitely a disaster.
Verdict: 5/10

I'm a fan of the matrix and I have to say that is an action movie like many others.  Far is the idea of ​​a work of art and the philosophy that surrounded the script.  The green filters that characterized each scene in the Matrix have disappeared, the agents as we know them do not exist, so they have lost their essence.  

The soundtrack for me is one of the worst things in the movie, with this I do not mean that the music is bad, but it is not the Matrix.  And no longer say that Neo is not represented as the chosen one but as a weak image of which only the shadow remains, empowering Trinitty with the power of flight, which makes no sense since she is not the ONE.  

In the scene where Trinitty is flying and Neo is not, she holds Neo and he is hanging, a ridiculous scene, since Neo, having sacrificed so much, appears so weak.

Like many fans, I found the originals absolutely mind-bending and the action sequences set my expectations for years after but times have changed and I loved Resurrections for entirely different reasons and how well it fits into our present moment.  

I loved that it takes some well-deserved swipes at the more vacuous aspects of the digital media and entertainment industries.  I loved its timely exploration of the meaning of "truth", personal choice, and the definition of sanity. I loved its self-awareness and meta-perspective on the place the original trilogy holds in the culture.  I loved that the cinematography is totally different, tighter, and more claustrophobic as if seeing something familiar through an entirely new lens.  I loved that Neo's love for Trinity is the core driver of the action rather than the messianic ideal of saving those who, as it turns out, really don't care to be saved.
